meanings.definition: Facing or moving in the direction from which the wind is blowing.
meanings.sent1: The sailor adjusted the sail to catch the windward breeze.
meanings.sent2: The house was built with a strong windward wall to protect it from the gusts.
meanings.sent3: The kite soared high in the windward sky, dancing with the playful gusts.
meanings.sent4: Her hair flew wildly in the windward air, like a flag in a storm.
meanings.sent5: The flag fluttered proudly on the windward side of the ship, leading the way.

meanings.definition: Located on or toward the side from which the wind is blowing.
meanings.sent1: The windward side of the tree was bent from years of facing the strong winds.
meanings.sent2: The tent was pitched on the windward edge of the camp to shield it from the breeze.
meanings.sent3: The windward window rattled in the night, as if whispering secrets to the storm.
meanings.sent4: The windward cliffs stood tall and proud, resisting the relentless winds.
meanings.sent5: The windward flag fluttered bravely, leading the way for the others to follow.

meanings.definition: In the direction from which the wind is coming.
meanings.sent1: The leaves rustled windward as the storm approached.
meanings.sent2: The birds flew swiftly windward, seeking shelter from the oncoming gale.
meanings.sent3: She turned windward, feeling the cool breeze on her face.
meanings.sent4: The ship sailed steadily windward, guided by the force of the wind.
meanings.sent5: The clouds moved slowly windward, painting the sky with shades of gray.
